reviewText:
Total Annihilation is the defining game of the RTS genre. Looking back to the late 90s and the technology available then, this game was amazingly advanced and did many things that weren't at all common then. Many common RTS elements that are expected in a game released today can be seen in their youth in TA. The order queuing system, the streaming resource and building systems, the diversity of units and asymmetrical factions are all key features that were later used in practically every RTS since. You can clearly see the foundation of Supreme Commander especially. There are aspects of TA that still haven’t been matched, such as the unit diversity: Air, Land, Sea, Seaplane, Hovercraft, Amphibious.

Like artillery? How about the Intimidator, which can fire halfway across the map? Too slow? Build the Buzzsaw: a giant rotary cannon made up of Intimidators that fires as fast as a machine gun and will drain your energy economy in seconds. Yes, it IS the most entertaining gun ever!

The music of TA is the best orchestral soundtrack ever made for a game. I still sometimes listen to the battle" tracks in my car. I turn the music off in every other game I’ve played and listen to “real” music instead (I remember listening to Spice Girls on a CD while playing)

reviewText:
Word of Warning it is a nostalgic game.

A true RTS Game that could be said to have out lasted Starcraft Brood War and inspired the next generation of Real Time Stratergy games, Remember fondly playing this game as a kid and back in the day it was perhaps one of the first community driven games that boasted thousands of mods and total conversions from Star Wars to the Modern World this game was much like the Skyrim of the 90's with an seemingly endless supply of units, mods, and creativity on the part of the community.

Unsurprisingly this hasn't changed, Total Annihilation still retains a small but solid community of players ranging from Casuals to Professionals all it covers all the basis for a RTS game but not without it's issues.

The base game is known to suffer from pathfinding issues, you'll frequently find that without the use of mods or modified scripts the AI will struggle considerably and will at times do stupid things that might ruin the experiance of players looking for a challenge, if that's you then I'd recommend either playing with friends or joining one of the many communities out their!

Or look into getting one of the many mods the game supports, most if not all improve the AI come to ruthless degrees where you'll hard pressed to both micro and marco manage an entire force of soulless machines. The best way I can descrbe it would be to think of Skyrim without mods, then think of Skyrim with mods that's effectively TA in a nuthshell.

Options:

+ The developers certainly had longevity in mind, you can adjust the resolution up to 1920 x 1080.
+ Provides all the options you might expect from a game of this age, perhaps abit more.
- On/Off only, you can't find a middle ground without adjusting the files directly.

Gameplay

+ A map for everybody! - every map has something for everybody the metal maps provide infinite resources and lead to a fast-paced style game. In contrast low metal maps have you fighting over resources while slowly pushing your way into the enemy base. Maps on distant moons have you transporting units by air over impassable chasms or bombing your opponent into the dust.

+ Play how you want - Many RTS games have a 'defined' stratergy TA has no such definition, you will encounter players who love the good old peepee rush or those whose sole purpose is to watch you squirm as they destroy your outlying extractors. You'll encounter the turtles naturally but the game provides you with all the nessesary tools to enact your stratergy and descimate others.

- AI Pathfinding - As mentioned the pathfinding is horrible and will almost certainly require fixing especially if you want to play Skirmish thankfully their are mods and simple scripts to fix this.

- Performance - Most modern day PC's won't have a problem until like Skyrim you hit a point where your computer begins to chug along. This tends to arise from heavily modded games especially when you start to up the unit cap from 200 to 1000+

Community:

+ Still going strong not much else to say here besides the fact you have over 10 years of mods to discover some of which have been developed over so many years.

reviewText:
My favorite game as a child, i quickly snapped up the DRM Free edition availible through GOG.com. Now OTA is here on Steam in all its glory! It wasnt Starcraft or Command & Conquer that set the bar for late 90s rts games. OTA is the undisputed and most refferenced old-school RTS that to this day inspires the finer qualities in the EPIC War genre we crave.

Its important to note *though steam failed to mention it in the product details* This edition includes all DLC along with the main game (Original Total Annihilation, Core contengency Expansion, All of the Battle Tactics Expansions, Bonus Maps, Bonus Official Cavedog Units, Patch 3.1 known as the No CD Patch" Patch 3.1 also is tweaked with the expanded unit cap which can be modified in the system files to a maximum of 5000 units per player in a 10 player battle. updated and fully supported multiplayer hosting for matches complete with thier own communities... The Added bennefit of the Steam Edition is access to the steam community for multiplayer compatibility. by comparison it is identical to the GOG edition with exception that the steam version has better compatibility with modern windows OS. Both copies work seamlessly with Wine if you use Linux or Mac. I reccomend the Steam edition for ease of gaming with friends. but the GOG.com version is DRM Free meaning you can buy one copy and then gift as many as you want to your friends per thier TOS agreement.

-----Some useful details about the game not mentioned in the description-----

Minor Bug: Due to this being a rather ancient game... there is an issue with the screen rendering of the game for flat screens which will cause a periodic flicker. Alt Tab didnt exist back then either so you should press the Windows key to minimise your game if you wish to chat with your steam buddies outside of the game. This however has an issue where the the screen will tweak out into odd colors... just minimize and maximize a couple times and the emulator steam uses to run the game will adjust and fix the issue pretty reliably. This is caused by the change in formatting for video displays after the flat screen transition.

Some Extra Stuff:

by default the multiplayer loby should have this enabled due to game additions added for both the GOG.com & Steam versions of the game. If you accidently shrink your lobby down or it appears as the old default of maximum of 4 players for skirmish and multi
date:
simply press the 8 key on your keyboard followed by the roman numeral key from 2 to 10 indicating the max player matches. so 2 would be "8 ii" while 10 would be "8 x".

to enter a "console code" while playing multiplayer or skirmish game modes simply press Enter and type + followed by the command. (The older versions of the game allowed some console commands to work in single player but the 3.1 patch made many commands nonfunctional or were removed all together. Many of these commands are now only availible within the develloper mode which you will need to download from TAUniverse & other fansites. It is possible to reinable them by editing the configuration files but the engine will not allow you to play multiplayer with other clients that have different files then you.)

some useful console commands are +gamma
hoursPlayed: & +showranges. These dont really break gameplay and fully function in all gamemodes
voteText:
so enabling cheats to use these functions is ok if you agree with your gamemates that they can be used.

+gamma lets you adjust the brightness of the screen "+gamma 8.5" was default for the old tube monitors... you can play around with this if you have lighting issues.

+contour is useful for seeing the 3D terrain elivations and is highly useful as nobody back then had a concept of strategic zoom like what was introduced by Supreme Commander. +contour 5 is best i think as it still lets you view the pretty terrain features while letting you put that factory on the perfect spot easier. type +contour with no number to remove the elivation overlay. if you put a value in decimal that is less then one you will need to place a zero before the decimal for it to register... note this can cause framerate loss or artificial slowdown of the game for really minor details. in case of a game crash you will need to reinstall yourgame if you input values lower then 0.045.

+showranges indicates the ranges of the various weapons on mobile units. it doesnt work on fixed fortifications which was fixed when they included the same feature in Supreme Commander. By default all units have an explosion range where they will harm other units within that range... and most units have 1 - 2 weapon ranges which might be off screen if its a long ranged weapon. some specdial units will by default have other indicators depending on functionality such as a cloak or stealth/jammer field that should be enabled by default.

a neat feature on the main menu is to type "dxdeath" which will enable or disable a Cavedog logo in the lower middle of the menuscreen. if you click that... in the old days it would allow you to view the credit screen... also while enabled it would allow you to manually pick missions rather then unlocking missions as you played.

--another 2 codes that are neat but may become annoying for various reasons are +sing & +dither.

+sing replaces the vehical sounds of units with a guy singing some nonsensical toon.

+dither changes the gray scale of the out of view zones in the game to a "dithered" or bug-screen colored view. it looked great on the old analog tube monitors but causes major flickering issues on modern digital flatscreens. DO NOT USE THIS IF YOU HAVE EPILEPSY or are at risk for seizures or taking medications with this risk (regular gameplay on flatscreens however is completely safe)... there is no warning for this feature as this game predates those videogame warnings by like 10 years."

reviewText:
This game is quite possibly the single greatest video game ever made. When it was released in 1997, Total Annihilation was so far ahead of its time that in some respects it has never been duplicated since.

At the time I write this review there is no Steamworks multiplayer or Workshop mod support. But if these things are implemented, I have no doubts whatsoever that we will see a huge resurgence of Total Annihilation. There are already tens of thousands of third-party units, many mega-mods of hundreds of units, total conversions for everything from Star Wars to WWII to Gundam, to entirely new games built on TA as a basis. The amount of strategic depth flowing from fairly simple rules of collecting metal from metal spots and using it to construct various types of units, using a continous economy, physics-based battles, and a serious need for planning and tactics rather than unit counter relationships, make Total Annihilation a much deeper and more interesting strategy game than most of its contemporary cousins, including Starcraft and Age of Empires.

Real time strategy games have been starved for ideas for many years now, with the most successful ones being sequels and spiritual successors to genuinely innovative strategy games from the '90s. Alongside Starcraft, Total Annihilation is one of the great progenitors of the modern era of strategy games, and in many respects it has never been equaled.

reviewText:
One of the best games of my high school years. I have played this game so much, I don't think any other game can compare. The modding community at the time was crazy, tons of new options to add in. You can still find mods to this day. The first one was great but the expansions added so much more to the game. For its time this game was the Farcry of RTS, graphics were amazing, maps were never ending, and battles were not capped to 200 units per player. Game defaults to 1000 units, however patchs are available, or a simple edit of the config file to allow as many as you desire.

When cavedog first offered their gaming service to connect players it was all I ever did. I finally had an endless amount of players to play with. It is just sad that the sequal to the game was such a downfall in the game play department. Seems to collopsed their mightly RTS empire.

I hope you all enjoy this game as much as I did.

Just some helpful hints to play the game, starting with before you actually play
It doesn't appear narration is available in the game, sad face. Maybe it is just mine. Secondly change left click to right click in the menus if your used to other RTS. Game sound starts at mono and can be changes to 3D (Stereo). Options accessed only once you select single or multiple player. Options in game can be selected by pressing tab. Game I believe is auto paused on start for all maps. Resolution support works for 1080p but must be selected, most games at this time barely supported 1280x1028.

While playing:
Speed can be adjusted during single and multiple player via the + or - buttons.
Multiple buildings can be queued together using shift.
Resource sharing is possible with allies at set increments so you never have to constantly send resources.
Building units also has an infinite queue. Holding shift increments 5. Left click to add units, right click to remove.
Your commander has a gun called the D-Gun hot key is D, this is a huge blast that can one shot everything but a commander and expieremental units not in the original (later expansions).
If your commander dies in campaign it is the end of the match, multiplayer depending on settings. Your commander blows up like a big nuke.
Planes build the slowest, then Kbots, then vechicles. Forgot hover vechicles, but they are in an expansion as well. Each one has different perks, and should be used together to cordinate strikes. However planes usually over power all else, as they are fast, hard to hit, and cheap to build.

reviewText:
I'm a pretty crappy writer so I apologize in advance.

Total Annihilation is an incredibly unique and intense RTS that was light-years ahead of its time and still is today. I still strongly prefer the original over the more spiritual-successor, Planetary Annihilation.

Total Annihilation features so many small features that just make it amazing, the battles can be huge and intense with massive amounts of units having a huge Warhammer 40k esque fight all on one screen, or the games can be slow and brilliantly thought out. This is a strategy game where you can win purely by 'defensive' play at times, something I find to be rather unique among a lot of strategy games that even today have rather narrow methods to win, usually by just having the larger and better offensive force, but not always in Total Annihilation.

A feature that makes Total Annihilation so unique is the true emphasis on a defensive playstyle, if you so desire. There are an impressive amount of options for defensive, slow play styles and faster, more offensive playstyles alike. You can choose to hunker down and improve your economy while building a large amount of turrets and upgrading to better ones over the course of the game, some are even capable of bombarding your opponent from the entire maps length, assuming you reach the demanding level of tech and economy required for them. Even tactical nukes can be constructed and launched over a map away if the game length and level of sustainable economy is reached. This allows for a lot of options for a lot of different types of players. There is also no real super demanding macro-memory required à la StarCraft II, making the game just a bit more accessable to newer players, especially in more team oriented game modes.

The game also features incredible physics for it's more 2.5 dimensional, isometric strategy experience. One of my favourite things about this game is seeing things like unit inaccuracy, especially when on the move or on unstable ground or even when taking pot-shots at something through the fog-of-war. Units will have better vision when on the high ground and worse vision when in a trench, making a lot of areas on maps incredibly strategic locations. There's even bullet physics, units will often adjust their aim higher or lower depending on the target, and when the steel corpses begin to litter the battlefield they will often block incoming rounds harmlessly while your units continue to trudge past the enemy fire. There's a gritty feeling seeing all your units charge an enemy fortified position only to begin seeing the missiles and rounds begin to rain down upon them and seeing a huge chunk of your force get obliterated by a large round, shaking the screen and sending chunks of steel flying in every direction, the steel gibs" even damaging nearby units who get hit by them.

The game also features an amazing orchestral 'dynamic' music score written and composed by the one and only Jeremy Soule. The music really compliments an already fantastic game nicely
date: changing to a more brooding tone as you build up your base and switching to a more heart-pounding score as enemy fighters engage your army. It's an incredible soundtrack that you may even consider finding for your own music player. The sound design alone in this game is also very unique and give it a great distinct and 'mechanical' feel.\n\nIf there was one strategy that I think is criminally unknown to most people

reviewText:
I cannot recommend the Steam version of TA for any player who wishes to play with more than the OTA natively supported max cap of 500 units.

As downloaded from Steam, the game defaults to 250 units and there is no TotalA.ini file, so you will have to download one or make your own. With the proper .ini file installed, the cap can then be safely raised to 500 units. However, if you want raise the cap any higher, it's necessary to install a different version of TotalA.exe (downloadable from several locations incl. TA Universe). This plus setting the unit cap to 1500 units in the .ini file will indeed give you a limit of 1500 units in the game, but there is a problem, and the cause seems to be the altered TotalA.exe file.

Playing with the TotalA.exe file downloaded from Steam and using the .ini file for 500 units, the game played fine all the way through to the end. But as soon as I replaced the default version of TotalA.exe with the version of TotalA.exe included in the 1500 unit patch from TA Universe, the game started consistently crashing whenever I would take my armada of aircraft over to start harassing the enemy base. This happened several times even though I only had about 500 total units at the time. About 200 of those were my aircraft. To eliminate sound as the issue, I tried disabling Direct Sound and using Windows sound instead, but the result was exactly the same.

My system is Windows 7 x64bit, and I have no mods installed yet. The ONLY difference between the two scenarios was the TotalA.exe file from TA Universe which is necessary to be able to raise the unit cap to 1500 units. The downloaded game from Steam was not changed in any other way.

I'm aware of a beta patch available from TA Universe but haven't tried it yet. I'm thinking about seeing if I can find my old TA disk and installing TA, TA:CC, and TA:BT with that, then patching to 3.1 and so on. If that does fix the issue, then the problem is with the Steam version of the game. So for now, I don't recommend buying the game from Steam because most people will want to exceed the 500 unit cap.

reviewText:
Initially I thought this was a great game until I discovered one particular bu****** mechanic. Since WHEN does a building count as a unit? In pretty much every RTS ever made, a unit is MOBILE, a character or vehicle with combat, constructive, or special abilities. Buildings are STATIONARY. They typically do nothing to defend your base and are used for production purposes. So, let's say you're expanding your base, fighting tooth and claw for metal, building solar complexes and also building DEFENSES to PROTECT what you've had to fight hard for. Laser towers on resource spots, production buildings abroad so you can deploy forces from key locations. Well guess what? This whole time you've been expanding your base, you have been taking space from your COMBAT UNITS.

There is a UNIT CAP. So now, if you do have an expanded base, there's a good chance the enemy has a larger fighting force than you and regardless of whether you attack or wait to be attacked, you'll take heavy casualties and the enemy will sense this and just overwhelm you with a larger army. Oh and the game DOESN'T tell you how close you're getting to the unit cap. So you basically have to finely tune the production of everything or else you might waste an hour and a half because your fighting units are crippled by the unit cap. This is the issue I've found in campaign and it's kind of horse s***.

In closing, why does a game called TOTAL ANNIHILATION, which is about the mass production of combat robots between two factions who have been hating each other for 400 years have this cap? It's like putting a diaper on a grizzly bear. Wherever we look, sentient robots are a HUGE problem. Terminator: the whole damn planet has been overrun with machines. Mass Effect: THE WHOLE F****** UNIVERSE is about to be destroyed by machines. Robots bring two things when they attack, firepower and numbers. In a game like Age of Empires it makes sense. Want to train more troops and villagers? You need more houses/castles for your people to shelter in. Robots don't give a f*** about rest and typically don't care about how much space is left on the planet, they just want to kill stuff!

My opinion has not changed in the nearly two decades that have passed since Total Annihilation's launch date; this is still a forward-thinking masterwork of the RTS genre, its eerily desolate atmosphere and lush, Jeremy Soule-composed score just as evocative as it was back then.

Total Annihilation was a standout title for many years after it was released, but due to inferior marketing, it went unnoticed by much of the gaming community.

A stellar Real-Time Strategy, TA gives the player two choices for playable factions. The protagonist race, the Arm, has been warring with the machine Core for an impossibly long time. The single-player campaign is typical for early RTSs--learn how to explore, unlock a few units at a time, and build up to large, long battles near the end. You can choose to play as either race in single player, and each one's story can be completed in ~10 hours.

The multiplayer and skirmish are where I spent most of my time when I played in the early 00s.

While the title set impressive standards in 3D modeling, realistic physics, detailed UI, and developing a still-active modding community, the age of the game is showing in 2016. AI pathfinding and base management is horrible, to put it plainly. Still, the graphics and soundtrack are as impressive as ever. I'm still amazed that this game was released in 1997.

The add-ons breathed amazing new life into the game when they were released. The Core Contingency adds an excellent single-player arc for each faction, and along with the story, many exciting new units.

This is a great game to relive the RTS glory days of the late 90s. Pick a copy up, gift a copy to a friend, and battle it out for a few exciting hours.

PS: If you love the style and controls, you will definitely want to get Supreme Commander, which was developed by the same lead and is regarded as the spiritual successor" of TA."

Total Annihilation was a standout title for many years after it was released, but due to inferior marketing, it went unnoticed by much of the gaming community.

A stellar Real-Time Strategy, TA gives the player two choices for playable factions. The protagonist race, the Arm, has been warring with the machine Core for an impossibly long time. The single-player campaign is typical for early RTSs--learn how to explore, unlock a few units at a time, and build up to large, long battles near the end. You can choose to play as either race in single player, and each one's story can be completed in ~10 hours.

The multiplayer and skirmish are where I spent most of my time when I played in the early 00s.

While the title set impressive standards in 3D modeling, realistic physics, detailed UI, and developing a still-active modding community, the age of the game is showing in 2016. AI pathfinding and base management is horrible, to put it plainly. Still, the graphics and soundtrack are as impressive as ever. I'm still amazed that this game was released in 1997.

The add-ons breathed amazing new life into the game when they were released. The Core Contingency adds an excellent single-player arc for each faction, and along with the story, many exciting new units.

This is a great game to relive the RTS glory days of the late 90s. Pick a copy up, gift a copy to a friend, and battle it out for a few exciting hours.

PS: If you love the style and controls, you will definitely want to get Supreme Commander, which was developed by the same lead and is regarded as the spiritual successor" of TA."

Total Annihilation is a ridiculously fun and addictive RTS game that was developed in 1997 by a little company called Cavedog. For an almost 20-year-old game, it's amazing how fun this game is to still play.

The user interface is very user-friendly, and the game itself is simple to learn. Despite the ease of being able to get into the game and just start playing, there is a wide variety of units that allow an incredible level of complex creativity in terms of strategy. Total Annihilation is like eating candy without the calories: it gives you a cool robot army, huge explosions, and probably one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard composed for a game.

Total Annihilation is also very mod-friendly and customizable.

Despite being a great game, there are some pitfalls: Getting a multiplayer game can be tricky if you have no idea what you're doing. You will need to connect to the ip address of the host, which most modern games do for you automatically. Additionally, there is a unit cap of 250 (which includes buildings) that you *can* increase, but you have to manually edit the totala.ini file. This can be a pain in the butt for the computer-challenged, but isn't difficult to actually do.

The main complaint I hear about this game is the pathfinding. And I agree. Sometimes your units will do what seem to be nonsensical things, like trying to drive up a wall instead of going around it. Very large armies also have difficulty moving around, and the units tend to get stuck on each other. Naval units are the best example of this, where they will grind against each other trying to find their way to a destination. There ARE pathfinding patches out there that will significantly help with these difficulties, though.

Overall, this is a great game. I highly recommend it for pretty much anyone ever.
